text.p: Bonds surged, although they slightly trailed Spain, on hopes that the Bank of Portugal will follow the Bundesbank in cutting the repo rate.
"The (German) rate cut gave a boost to the periphery markets and we went up with Spain," said one trader.

"Tomorrow there could be some initial profit-taking in periphery markets, particularly if the central banks (Spain and Portugal) disappoint and do not ease monetary policy," said another trader. But even in this case, the retreat would not be too great and the markets would find support a little below current levels, he added.
"The spreads would not change much," he added, referring to the yield gap between the Spanish and the Portuguese 10-year cash bonds.
The trader added that if Spain and Portugal cut, then the markets could push higher and the spread narrow below 10 basis points.
According to analysts polled by Reuters, the Bank of Portugal could cut its 7.5 percent repo by up to 25 basis points on Friday.
